title: Linear Models
text: Motivation: Danceability

title: Linear Models
text:
Empty Model

Find the Mean of all the data
\[
\hat Y_i =  mean
\]
The predicted value is \(\hat Y_i\)

title: Linear Models
text: Find the Empty Model

title: Linear Models
text:
SSE of the Empty Model
\[
SSE = \sum^n_{i=1}(Y_i-\hat Y_i)^2
\]

For each data point

Find the predicted value
Obtain the residual value (\(Y_i-\hat Y_i\))
Square the residual \((Y_i-\hat Y_i)^2\)

Repeat the process for all data points
Add up all the squared Residuals

\[

\]

title: Linear Models
text:
Modelling Danceability with Album
We want to see if album can explain danceability.

title: Linear Models
text:
Modelling an outcome with categorical

Compute the means for each group
Identify the number of predictor variables (inputs, independent, X, Z, …) to explain the outcome variable (Y)

You need one less the number of categories

Construct the generic model

\(\hat Y_i = b_0 + b_1 X\): for 2 categories
\(\hat Y_i = b_0 + b_1 X + b_2Z\): for 3 categories
\(\hat Y_i = b_0 + b_1 X + b_2 Z + b_3 A + \cdots\) : for 4 or more categories

Define each variable to indicate category

\(1\): for a specific category
\(0\): for other
Known as indicator variable

Set the mean for each group equal to the model with appropriate indicator variable values
Solve for the coefficients \(b_0, b_1, b_2, \ldots\) using algebra
Construct final model with numerical values

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Real or Random

Does smoking have a protective effect on having a premature infant?


Does the number of hospital visits have a protective effect?


What is real and what is random?

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Hypothesis Tests
Hypothesis tests are used to test whether claims are valid or not. This is conducted by collecting data, setting the Null and Alternative Hypothesis.

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Null Hypothesis \(H_0\)
The null hypothesis is the claim that is initially believed to be true. For the most part, it is always equal to the hypothesized value.

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Alternative Hypothesis \(H_a\)
The alternative hypothesis contradicts the null hypothesis.

title: Hypothesis Testing
section: Example of Null and Alternative Hypothesis
text:
Example of Null and Alternative Hypothesis
We want to see if \(\beta\) is different from \(\beta^*\)



Null Hypothesis
Alternative Hypothesis




\(H_0: \beta=\beta^*\)
\(H_a: \beta\ne\beta^*\)


\(H_0: \beta\le\beta^*\)
\(H_a: \beta>\beta^*\)


\(H_0: \beta\ge\beta^*\)
\(H_0: \beta<\beta^*\)

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
One-Side vs Two-Side Hypothesis Tests
Notice how there are 3 types of null and alternative hypothesis, The first type of hypothesis (\(H_a:\beta\ne\beta^*\)) is considered a 2-sided hypothesis because the rejection region is located in 2 regions. The remaining two hypotheses are considered 1-sided because the rejection region is located on one side of the distribution.



Null Hypothesis
Alternative Hypothesis
Side




\(H_0: \beta=\beta^*\)
\(H_a: \beta\ne\beta^*\)
2-Sided


\(H_0: \beta\le\beta^*\)
\(H_a: \beta>\beta^*\)
1-Sided


\(H_0: \beta\ge\beta^*\)
\(H_0: \beta<\beta^*\)
1-Sided

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Decision Making
Hypothesis Testing will force you to make a decision: Reject \(H_0\) OR Fail to Reject \(H_0\)

Reject \(H_0\): The effect seen is not due to random chance, there is a process making contributing to the effect.


Fail to Reject \(H_0\): The effect seen is due to random chance. Random sampling is the reason why an effect is displayed, not an underlying process.

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Decision Making: P-Value
The p-value approach is one of the most common methods to report significant results. It is easier to interpret the p-value because it provides the probability of observing our test statistics, or something more extreme, given that the null hypothesis is true.

If \(p < \alpha\), then you reject \(H_0\); otherwise, you will fail to reject \(H_0\).

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Decision Making: Confidence Interval Approach
The confidence interval approach can evaluate a hypothesis test where the alternative hypothesis is \(\beta\ne\beta^*\). The bootstrapping approach will result in a lower and upper bound denoted as: \((LB, UB)\).

If \(\beta^*\) is in \((LB, UB)\), then you fail to reject \(H_0\). If \(\beta^*\) is not in \((LB,UB)\), then you reject \(H_0\).

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Significance Level \(\alpha\)
The significance level \(\alpha\) is the probability you will reject the null hypothesis given that it was true.

In other words, \(\alpha\) is the error rate that a research controls.


Typically, we want this error rate to be small (\(\alpha = 0.05\)).

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Hypothesis Test Process


Set up the Null and Alternative Hypothesis.

\(H_0: \beta = 0\) and \(H_a: \beta \ne 0\)

Compute p-value or confidence interval
Make a decision
Interpret the results

Code

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Sampling Distribution is the idea that the statistics that you generate (slopes and intercepts) have their own data generation process.

In other words, the numerical values you obtain from the lm and glm function can be different if we got a different data set.


Some values will be more common than others. Because of this, they have their own data generating process, like the outcome of interest has it’s own data generating process.




\[
Y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_i + \varepsilon_i
\]

\(Y_i\): Outcome data
\(X_i\): Predictor data
\(\beta_0, \beta_1\): parameters
\(\varepsilon_i\): error term




\[
\varepsilon_i \sim DGP
\]


The error terms forces the outcome variable to be different from the mathematical model.
The numbers being generated are random and cannot be predicted.

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Inference
In the real world, we do not know how the model is generated; therefore, the parameters that are being estimated are unknown.

We use statistics to determine what is our best guess of what the true parameter is.


We can use processes known as inferential procedures to determine which values of the parameter it cannot be. This is known as inference.

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Hypothesis Tests
Hypothesis tests are used to test whether claims are valid or not. This is conducted by collecting data, setting the Null and Alternative Hypothesis.

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Null Hypothesis \(H_0\)
The null hypothesis is the claim that is initially believed to be true. For the most part, it is always equal to the hypothesized value.

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Alternative Hypothesis \(H_a\)
The alternative hypothesis contradicts the null hypothesis.

title: Randomization Tests
section: Example of Null and Alternative Hypothesis
text:
Example of Null and Alternative Hypothesis
We want to see if \(\mu\) (the true value) is different from \(\mu_0\) (a number we want to test)



Null Hypothesis
Alternative Hypothesis




\(H_0: \mu=\mu_0\)
\(H_a: \mu\ne\mu_0\)


\(H_0: \mu\le\mu_0\)
\(H_a: \mu>\mu_0\)


\(H_0: \mu\ge\mu_0\)
\(H_0: \mu<\mu_0\)

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Hypothesis Test
The idea of hypothesis testing is to generate the sampling distribution of a statistic assuming the null hypothesis is true.

Compute the statistic from your data.


Afterwards, see where your statistic lies in comparison of your null sampling distribution.

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Comparison of Null Distribution
If your statistic lies near the mounds, it is believed that your data came from the null distribution.
If your statistic is more in the tail regions, it is believed that your data did not come from your null distribution.

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Motivation
The bacteria data set contians information on whether bacteria (y: y or n) is present after utilizing treatments (ap: active or placebo).

We are interesting in determine the proportion of having bacteria present is different for those taking an “active” or “placebo”.

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Crosstabulation


Code
cat_stats(bacteria$ap, bacteria$y)

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Comparing Proportions
We are interesting in determining if different groups see different proportions of a binary outcome.
We compute the proportions of observing the binary outcome in Group 1 and Group 2 and see if they are fundamentally different from each other.

title: Randomization Tests
text:
2 by 2 Cross Tabulations



Groups
Outcome 1
Outcome 2


Group 1
\(p_{11}\)
\(p_{21}\)


Group 2
\(p_{12}\)
\(p_{22}\)




We want to compare \(p_{11}\) and \(p_{12}\), to determine if the probability of outcome 1 are the same for both groups.

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Test Statistic
We can use both \(p_{11}\) and \(p_{12}\) to determine if there is a fundamental difference.

However, it will be more beneficial to utilize one statistic to contruct the sampling distribution.


\[
T =  p_{11} - p_{12}
\]

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Obtain Proportion in R


Code
props(DATA$GROUP, DATA$OUTCOME, VAL)

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Obtain Difference in R


Code
props(DATA$GROUP, DATA$OUTCOME, VAL, diff = TRUE)

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Bacteria Example


Code
props(bacteria$ap, bacteria$y, "y")


#>     a     p 
#> 0.750 0.875

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Bacteria Example


Code
props(bacteria$ap, bacteria$y, "y", TRUE)


#> [1] 0.125

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Hypothesis Test
Is 12.5% of a difference large enough to indicate that an active drug is effective against the bacteria, or seeing this can be due to random chance.

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Hypotheis Test
We will test the following hypothesis:
\[
H_0:\ p_1-p_2 = 0
\]
\[
H_a:\ p_1 - p_2 \neq 0
\]

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Hypothesis Test
In words:
\(H_0\): The variables bacteria presence and active drug treatment are independent of each other.
\(H_a\): The variables bacteria presence and active drug treatment are dependent of each other.

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Visualizing


Code
ab <- cat_stats(bacteria$y[bacteria$ap == "a"], pie = TRUE)
abp <- ggplot(ab, aes(fill = Category, values = n)) +
  geom_waffle(make_proportional = TRUE) + 
  ggtitle("Active Treatment") +
  theme_void() +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5))

pb <- cat_stats(bacteria$y[bacteria$ap == "p"], pie = TRUE)
pbp <- ggplot(pb, aes(fill = Category, values = n)) +
  geom_waffle(make_proportional = TRUE) +
  ggtitle("Placebo") +
  theme_void() +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5))



abp + pbp + plot_layout(guides = 'collect')

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Randomization Tests
The idea of a randomization test is that each observed outcome variable was dictated by a mathematical model.

Therefore, a randomization is most interested to determine if the mathematical model exist or completely random.


This is equivalent to saying the there is not pattern in the data. IE, independent variables.

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Randomization Tests
\(H_0\): The outcome and predictor variables are independent of each other.
\(H_a\): The outcome and predictor variables are dependent of each other.

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Randomization Test
The act of randomizing the outcome to a set of predictor variables allow you to construct the sampling of distribution of the null hypothesis.

\(H_0\): The variables bacteria presence and active drug treatment are independent of each other. \(p_{active}-p_{placebo} = 0\)
\(H_a\): The variables bacteria presence and active drug treatment are dependent of each other. \(p_{active}-p_{placebo} \neq 0\)

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Simulating \(H_0\)
We are interested in simulating the distribution for \(p_{active}-p_{placebo}\). We do this by randomly assigning the observed outcomes to the predictor variable. Then, we compute the difference in proportions using the props function. Afterwards, we store the value and repeat the process again.

Lastly, we compare where the data statistic compared to our simulated distribution.

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Shuffling Data
The shuffle function will mix up a variable in R:


Code
shuffle(VECTOR)

title: Randomization Tests

text:
The replicate Function
The replicate function will execute a task multiple times and store the values in a vector.


Code
replicate(N, FUN)



N: number of simulations
FUN: the command to be repeated

title: Randomization Tests
text:
P-Value
The p-value determines the probability of observing our data statistic, given that the null hypothesis is true.

When the p-value is large, we believe there is a high probability that the null hypothesis is true.


When the p-value is small, we believe that it is unlikely the the null hypothesis is true. We believe that the alternative may be a better model.

title: Randomization Tests
text:
2-Sided P-Value
Due to randomness, there is a possibility of observing the same magnitude of \(p_{active}-p_{placebo}\), but in the opposite direction; therefore, we must look at both sides.

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Visually 2-Sided P-Value


Code
ggplot(data.frame(x = sim_stats), aes(x)) + 
  geom_density() +
  geom_vline(xintercept = c(-1,1) *test_stat)

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Computing the p-value
We will count how many simulated \(p_{active}-p_{placebo}\)’s are more extreme than our test statistic and divided by the number of simulations plus one.

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Computing the p-value
\[
p = \frac{m +1}{N + 1}
\]

\(m\): number of more extreme values than our test statistic
\(N\): number of simulations

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Computing the P-Value


Code
(sum(abs(SIM_VECTOR) > abs(TEST_STAT)) + 1) / (N + 1)

title: Randomization Tests
text:
Computing P-value


Code
sum(abs(sim_stats) > abs(test_stat)) / 1001


#> [1] 0.01998002

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
The bacteria data set contians information on whether bacteria (y: y or n) is present after utilizing treatments (ap: active or placebo).

We are interesting in determine the proportion of having bacteria present is different for those taking an “active” or “placebo”.




We are interesting in determining if different groups see different proportions of a binary outcome.
We compute the proportions of observing the binary outcome in Group 1 and Group 2 and see if they are fundamentally different from each other.






Groups
Outcome 1
Outcome 2


Group 1
\(p_{11}\)
\(p_{21}\)


Group 2
\(p_{12}\)
\(p_{22}\)




We want to compare \(p_{11}\) and \(p_{12}\), to determine if the probability of outcome 1 are the same for both groups.




We can use both \(p_{11}\) and \(p_{12}\) to determine if there is a fundamental difference.

However, it will be more beneficial to utilize one statistic to contruct the sampling distribution.


\[
T =  \hat p_{11} - \hat p_{12}
\]






Code
props_df(DATA, GROUP, OUTCOME, VAL, diff = TRUE)







Code
props_df(bacteria, ap, y, "y")


#>    p1    p2 
#> 0.750 0.875







Code
props_df(bacteria, ap, y, "y", TRUE)


#> [1] 0.125

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
The bacteria data set contians information on whether bacteria (y: y or n) is present after utilizing treatments (ap: active or placebo).

We are interesting in determine the proportion of having bacteria present is different for those taking an “active” or “placebo”.

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
We are interesting in determining if different groups see different proportions of a binary outcome.
We compute the proportions of observing the binary outcome in Group 1 and Group 2 and see if they are fundamentally different from each other.

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
Groups
Outcome 1
Outcome 2


Group 1
\(p_{11}\)
\(p_{21}\)


Group 2
\(p_{12}\)
\(p_{22}\)




We want to compare \(p_{11}\) and \(p_{12}\), to determine if the probability of outcome 1 are the same for both groups.

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
We can use both \(p_{11}\) and \(p_{12}\) to determine if there is a fundamental difference.

However, it will be more beneficial to utilize one statistic to contruct the sampling distribution.


\[
T =  \hat p_{11} - \hat p_{12}
\]

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
Code
props_df(DATA, GROUP, OUTCOME, VAL, diff = TRUE)

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
Code
props_df(bacteria, ap, y, "y")


#>    p1    p2 
#> 0.750 0.875

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
Code
props_df(bacteria, ap, y, "y", TRUE)


#> [1] 0.125

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
Hypothesis Test
Is \(T = .125\) of a difference large enough to indicate that an active drug is effective against the bacteria, or seeing this can be due to random chance.

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
Hypotheis Test
We will test the following hypothesis:
\[
H_0:\ \Delta =  p_1-p_2 = 0
\]
\[
H_a:\ \Delta = p_1 - p_2 \neq 0
\]

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
Hypothesis Test


Code
sim_stats <- replicate(1000, props(bacteria$ap, shuffle(bacteria$y), "y", T))
test_stat <- props(bacteria$ap, bacteria$y, "y", T)
sum(abs(sim_stats) > abs(test_stat)) / 1001


#> [1] 0.01498501


Code
ggplot(data.frame(x = sim_stats), aes(x)) + 
  geom_density() +
  geom_vline(xintercept = test_stat)

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
Hypothesis test


What if \(\Delta = - 0.5\)?
What if \(\Delta = 0.5\)?
What if \(\Delta = - 0.25\)?
What if \(\Delta = 0.25\)?



Can we determine the plausible values of \(\Delta\) that may have produced our data set?

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
Standard Error
The standard error is the standard deviation of a statistic.

It can give us a margin of error for the statistic that we compute from the data.

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
Confidence Intervals
Confidence Intervals give you a collection of values that may contain the true parameter of interest.

The probability of capturing the true parameter is known as the confidence. This value can take any number between 0% to 100%

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
Confidence Interval
The confidence interval were displayed as: X%: (L, U)

title: The Bootstrap Method
text: Confidence Interval Intepretation

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
Confidence Intervals
These are a collection of \(\Delta\) values that will fail to reject the Null Hypothesis.

The \(\Delta\) values that are not different from our current estimate \(T\)

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
Confidence Intervals


Code
data.frame(x = rnorm(1000, 0.15, 0.05)) |> 
  ggplot(aes(x)) + 
  geom_density() +
  geom_vline(xintercept = test_stat)

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
Confidence Intervals


Code
data.frame(x = rnorm(1000, 0.075, 0.05)) |> 
  ggplot(aes(x)) + 
  geom_density() +
  geom_vline(xintercept = test_stat)

title: The Bootstrap Method
section: How to construct the DGP centered around \(\Delta\)?
text:
How to construct the DGP centered around \(\Delta\)?

Bootstrapping Techniques


Mathematical Models

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
Bootstrapping Techniques
Bootstrapping is a technique to determine which \(\Delta = p_1-p_2\) values, or any other statistic, will not be significantly different than \(T\).

Bootstrapping will simulate several fake data sets from the DGP of the data. Afterwards, each data set will produce a statistic to construct the sampling distribution.

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
Bootstrap Theory

The data set was generated from a distribution called \(f\).


\(f\) is unknown, we will sample from \(\hat f\) generated from the data.


When \(n \rightarrow \infty\), then \(\hat f\rightarrow f\)


So long as \(n\) is sufficiently large, the DGP of a statistic will be generated.

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
Bootstrapping Algorithm

Resample the data set using the resample() function
Compute the statistic of interest
Store the statistic
Repeat steps 1-3, until you a high number of simulations
Compute the confidence interval or standard errors from the bootstrap estimates

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
Bootstrapping in R
The resample() will create a new data set by sampling the old data set with replacement.


Code
boot1 <- resample(bacteria)
props_df(boot1, ap, y, yval = "y", TRUE)


#> [1] 0.130291

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
Repeat Process
Use the replicate() function to repeat this process a high number of times.


Code
boot_samples <-replicate(1000, 
                         props_df(resample(bacteria), ap, y, yval = "y", TRUE))

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
Bootstrap Distribution


Code
ggplot(data.frame(x = boot_samples), aes(x)) +
  geom_histogram() + 
  geom_vline(xintercept = test_stat)

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
Bootstrap-Based Standard Error


Code
sd(boot_samples)


#> [1] 0.05044719

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
Interpreting the SE
\[
0.125 \pm 0.05
\]

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
95% Confidence Interval


Code
ggplot(data.frame(x = boot_samples), aes(x)) +
  geom_histogram(aes(fill = middle(x, .95))) + 
  geom_vline(xintercept = test_stat)

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
95% Confidence Interval


Code
quantile(boot_samples, probs = c(0.025, 0.975))


#>       2.5%      97.5% 
#> 0.02499504 0.22086102

title: The Bootstrap Method
text:
Interpretation
We are 95% confident that the true difference in proportion (\(\Delta\)) is captured between the ranges (0.025, 0.224).

Critical reasoning using a quantitative and statistical, problem-solving approach to solving real-world problems. Topics include: probability and statistics, sample data, probability and empirical data distributions, sampling techniques, estimation and hypothesis testing, ANOVA, and correlation and regression analysis. Students will use standard statistical software to analyze real-world and simulated data. GenEd: B4

Reason both inductively and deductively with quantitative information and data

Write the results of a statistical study and draw conclusion in reports

Participation is based on short writing assignments conducted in class. There will be no make ups for these writing prompts.



Notebook assignments are designed to expand your statistical knowledge. These will be completed in Google Colab which can be accessed from Canvas. There is one notebook assignments every week that you can be completed during class time. The notebook assignment will be due on Wednesday at 11:59 PM every week.



Reading assignments are designed to teach you different statistical concepts and R Programming. As the course progresses, many of the concepts build on each other. Therefore, the assignments encourage you to read each chapter in an appropriate amount of time. You must read the chapter and answer the questions by the Sunday night at 11:59 PM. The 3 lowest reading assignments will be dropped.



Videos are used to teach statistical concepts related to the course. Students are expected to watch at least one video a week. The videos are implemented using PlayPosit, where questions are embedded in the video to check for understanding. The videos may require students to program and/or read research articles.



There will be three in exams. Exam #1 will be on Sept 30, Exam #2 will be on Nov 13, and Exam #3 will be on Dec 11 at 8-10 AM (Sec 01) or Dec 9 1-3 PM (Sec 02). While the exams are not considered cumulative, the material builds on each other. Developing a strong understanding of the material through out the course is important for your success. title: Categorical Data
text:
R Packages

csucistats
tidyverse
ggtricks
ggmosaic
waffle

title: Categorical Data
text:
Background
In October 2023, James Hoffman and Cometeer held the “Great American Coffee Taste Test” on YouTube, asking viewers to fill out a survey and coffee ordered from Cometeer.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Data
The data is part of DSLC Tidy Tuesday program where data sets are provided to help data science learners how to create graphics.
Information on the data sets variables (columns) can be found here.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Data


Code
library(csucistats)
library(ggtricks)
library(waffle)
library(ggmosaic)
library(tidyverse)
library(ThemePark)
library(DT)
coffee <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2024/2024-05-14/coffee_survey.csv")
datatable(slice_sample(coffee, n = 10), options = list(dom = "p", pageLength = 5))

title: Categorical Data
text:
Categorical Data
Categorical data are data recordings that represented a category.

Data may be recorded as a “character” or “string” data.


Data may be recorded as a whole number, with an attached code book indicating the categories each number belongs to.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Examples of Categorical Data


Are you a student?
What city do you live in?
What is your major?

title: Categorical Data
text:
Likert Scale
Likert scales are the rating systems you may have answered in surveys.


Strongly Disagree
Disagree
Neutral
Agree
Strongly Agree

title: Categorical Data
text:
Likert Scales
Likert scales may be treated as numerical data if the jumps between scales are equal.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Summarizing Categorical Data
Once we have the data, how do we summarize it to other people.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Continguency Tables
Continguency tables display how often a category is seen in the data.

There are two types of statistics that are reported in a table, the frequency and proportion.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Frequencey
Frequency represents the count of observing a specific category in your sample.


#>  [1] "2" "1" "2" "1" "1" "1" "2" "1" "2" "1"

title: Categorical Data
text:
Proportions (relative frequencey)
Proportions represent the percentage that the category represents the sample.

This allows you to generalize your sample to the population, regardless of sample size.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Continguency Tables in R
The variable caffeine indicates how much caffeine a participant prefers.

cat_stats(coffee$caffeine)

title: Categorical Data
text:
Plotting in R
Plotting in R can be done via the ggplot2, a powerful library based on the Grammar of Graphics.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Plotting in R

You need to create a base plot using the ggplot()
Use the + to change the look of the base plot
Indicate how to transform the base plot to the desired plot
geom_*
stat_*
Change the look of the plot with other functions
Use a theme_* function to add a theme to the plot

title: Categorical Data
text:
Bar Plots
Bar Plots can be used to display the frequency or proportions on the data.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Frequency Bar Plots in R

ggplot(data = DATA, aes(x = VARIABLE)) +
  geom_bar()

title: Categorical Data
text:
Frequency Bar Plots in R


Code
ggplot(coffee, aes(caffeine)) +
  geom_bar()

title: Categorical Data
section: Relative Frequency Bar Plots in R
text:
Relative Frequency Bar Plots in R

ggplot(data = DATA, aes(x = VARIABLE, y = after_stat(prop), group = 1)) +
  geom_bar()

title: Categorical Data
section: Relative Frequency Bar Plots in R
text:
Relative Frequency Bar Plots in R


Code
ggplot(coffee, aes(caffeine, after_stat(prop), group = 1)) +
  geom_bar()

title: Categorical Data
text:
Cross-Tabulation
Cross Tabulations allow you to see how data points are divided when looking at 2 different categorical variables.

title: Categorical Data
text:

The variable taste indicates if the participants like the taste of coffee.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Cross Tabulations

cat_stats(coffee$caffeine, coffee$taste)

title: Categorical Data
text:
Table Proportions

cat_stats(coffee$caffeine, coffee$taste, prop = "table")

title: Categorical Data
text:
Row Proportions

cat_stats(coffee$caffeine, coffee$taste, prop = "row")

title: Categorical Data
text:
Column Proportions

cat_stats(coffee$caffeine, coffee$taste, prop = "col")

title: Categorical Data
text:
Stacked Bar Plot in R

ggplot(DATA, aes(x = VAR1, y = after_stat(count), fill = VAR2)) +
  geom_bar()

title: Categorical Data
text:
Stacked Bar Plot in R

ggplot(coffee, aes(x = caffeine, y = after_stat(count), fill = taste)) +
  geom_bar()

title: Categorical Data
text:
Stacked Bar Plot in R

ggplot(coffee, aes(y = caffeine, x = after_stat(count), fill = taste)) +
  geom_bar()

title: Categorical Data
text:
Pie Charts
Pie charts are useful methods to show how a categories are related to each other in a sample.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Pie Chart in R

df_pie <- cat_stats(DATA$VARIABLE, pie = TRUE)
ggplot(df_pie, aes(cat = Category, val = n, fill = Category)) +
  geom_pie()

title: Categorical Data
text:
Pie Chart in R

coffee_pie <- cat_stats(coffee$caffeine, pie = TRUE)
ggplot(coffee_pie, aes(cat = Category, val = n, fill = Category)) +
  geom_pie()

title: Categorical Data
text:
Mosiac Plots
Mosiac Plots are usful in visualizing two categorical variables with its relative proportions.


#> Warning: The `scale_name` argument of `continuous_scale()` is deprecated as of ggplot2 3.5.0.


#> Warning: The `trans` argument of `continuous_scale()` is deprecated as of ggplot2 3.5.0.
#> ℹ Please use the `transform` argument instead.


#> Warning: `unite_()` was deprecated in tidyr 1.2.0.
#> ℹ Please use `unite()` instead.
#> ℹ The deprecated feature was likely used in the ggmosaic package.
#>   Please report the issue at <https://github.com/haleyjeppson/ggmosaic>.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Mosiac Plots in R

ggplot(DATA) +
  geom_mosaic(aes(x = product(VARIABLE), fill = VARIABLE))

title: Categorical Data
text:
Mosiac Plots in R

ggplot(coffee) +
  geom_mosaic(aes(x = product(caffeine, taste), fill = taste))

title: Categorical Data
text: Waffle Charts

title: Categorical Data
text:
Waffle Charts
Waffle Charts is similar to the pie charts where you can visualize the proportions.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Waffle Charts in R

df_pie <- cat_stats(DATA$VARIABLE, pie = TRUE)
ggplot(df_pie, aes(cat = Category, values = n)) +
  geom_waffle(make_proportional = TRUE)

title: Categorical Data
text:
Waffle Charts in R

coffee_pie <- cat_stats(coffee$caffeine, pie = TRUE)
ggplot(coffee_pie, aes(fill = Category, values = n)) +
  geom_waffle(make_proportional = TRUE)

title: Categorical Data
text:
Themes
The R packages ThemePark and ggthemes allows you to change the overall look of a plot.

All you need to do is add the theme to the plot.
